revision.revremark: Added 'Side Effects' and Transaction Processing Considerations'.
Added two functions: get_cmp_jobs and get_run_jobs
Added two arguments to new_job; added get_method_table function.
Added 'Aborting Job' section and five API functions.

abstract.para: An Application Programming Interface (API) to the Spk Database is defined. The descriptions in this document are independent of any particular programming language.

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para:
A relational database plays a central role in the architecture of Spk, because it is the means by which the major independent components communicate with one another and because it is the basis for implementation of a central feature of the design, known as the
Job History Model .

In order to operate a relational database, it is necessary to have a relational database management system (RDBMS). Because Spk will be distributed under an open source license, the open source MySQL RDBMS will be used. MySQL has all the features required by Spk and has a very large user base.

All of the widely used RDBMS share many similarities. They implement certain underlying concepts based on the work of E.F.Codd (see for example
A Relational Model of Data for Large Shared Data Banks ) and many others, which define what a relational database is and does. They all provide a high-level interface language known as the Structured Query Language (SQL). Most also provide standard vendor-independent interfaces based on popular programming languages such as C, Java, and Perl. These interfaces are known as Application Programming Interfaces (API). At a fundamental level, Spk will rely on these standard APIs so that it will be possible to substitute another RDBMS for MySQL, if necessary.

In order to insure the integrity of the database as information is added and modified, it is desirable to limit interactions with the database to a small body of well-tested code. For this reason, Spk includes its own high-level API, which caters directly to the needs of the MDA, Aspk and Cspk, and hence eliminates any need for these components to use the low-level APIs directly. This Spk-specific API is the topic of this document.

The functions of the Spk API are described in a language independent manner. There are three language-specific implementations of the API, known as language bindings. The Spk Database API has a Java binding, a C binding, and a Perl binding to satisfy the needs of the MDA, the Aspk and the Cspk, respectively.

This specification can be best understood with reference to the following related documents:
Job History Model
Database Entity-Relationship Model
Database Schema

sect1.title: Usage Scenario
sect1.para: When a user decides to run a set of scientific data against a model, she calls upon the Spk MDA running on her workstation to submit the model and data as a job. The MDA transmits this information across the Internet to a process known as the MDA Surrogate, which runs on a web server. The MDA Surrogate then creates a job by adding a row to the job table of the database, with the model in the xml_model field and the data in the xml_data field. The state_code field of this new row is set to the value 'q2c' thus adding the job to the compiler queue. This queue is a logical entity based on values stored in the job table, rather than a physical entity in which records are added and deleted.

Running independently, either on the machine that runs the web server or on some other machine, an idle Aspk Compiler queries the compiler queue by searching the job table for jobs with state_code equal to 'q2c' and selects the one which has the highest priority. In a logical sense, it removes the job from the compiler queue when it changes the state_code from 'q2c' to 'cmp'. The job is not removed from the job table, however. Jobs are never deleted from this table.

The process by which the Aspk Compiler selects the highest priority job that has state_code equal to 'q2c' and changes the state_code to 'cmp' must occur atomically, because there may be several instances of the Compiler trying to do the same thing simultaneously.

Having selected a job to compile, the Aspk Compiler proceeds to transform the model source into the C++ language. If it encounters errors, it adds an error report to the report field of the job, sets the state_code field to 'end' and the end_code field to 'cerr'. It is then idle and can scan for another job to compile.

If the Aspk Compiler succeeds in compiling the model, it updates job by storing its output in the cpp_source field and changing the state_code to 'q2r'. The Compiler is then idle and can scan for another job to compile.

When a Cspk becomes idle, it queries the run queue by selecting the highest priority job which has state_code equal to 'q2r'. It logically removes the job from the queue by setting the state_code to 'run'. The selection and the changing of state must occur as an atomic transaction, because there may be another Cspk process trying to select the highest priority job at the same time.

When the Cpsk has finished running the job, it updates the job table by storing the results of the computation in the report field, setting state_code to 'end' and end_code to 'srun'. The Cspk is then idle and can scan the queue for another job to run.

The MDA via its MDA Surrogate, periodically queries the database to discover whether or not any of its user's outstanding jobs have reached the End state. When it discovers that one has, it retrieves the contents of the report field and presents them to the user.

sect1.title: Aborting Job
sect1.para: When a user decides to abort a job, the MDA sets the state_code field of the job row to indicate that the job is aborted or should be aborted by one of the daemons.
If the current state_code is 'q2c', the MDA sets the job's state_code to 'end' and the job's end_code to 'abrt'.

If the current state_code is 'cmp', the MDA sets the job's state_code to 'q2ac'. The compiler daemon visits the database every second. When the compiler daemon finds the job, it changes the state_code to 'acmp' and sends a termination signal to the process executing the compiler instance for the job. When the process terminates, the compiler daemon sets the job's state_code to 'end' and the job's end_code to 'abrt'.
If the current state_code is 'q2r', the MDA sets the job's state_code to 'end' and the job's end_code to 'abrt'.

If the current state_code is 'run', the MDA sets the job's state_code to 'q2ar'. The run-time daemon visits the database every second. When the run-time daemon finds the job, it changes the state_code to 'arun' and sends a termination signal to the process executing the SPK driver instance for the job. When the process terminates, the run-time daemon sets the job's state_code to 'end' and the job's end_code to 'abrt'.

If the compiler daemon is shutdown in the middle of a job abortion, it may leave jobs with state_code 'q2ac' or 'acmp'. When the compiler daemon is restarted, it sets the job's state_code to 'end' and the job's end_code to 'abrt'.

If the run-time daemon is shutdown in the middle of a job abortion, it may leave jobs with state_code 'q2ar' or 'arun'. When the run-time daemon is restarted, it sets the job's state_code to 'end' and the job's end_code to 'abrt'. In the later case, there may be a checkpoint file in the working directory of the job. The daemon copies the text content of the checkpoint file to the database if there is one.

sect1.title: Functions
sect1.para: In this section the individual API functions will be described. Although they are referred to as functions here, they are implemented as subroutines in the Perl language and as class methods in Java. The descriptions below define those properties that are independent of language binding.

sect2.title: Data Types Used in Function Specifications
sect2.para:
Data types are language dependent. Because we are dealing with data fields that are defined in SQL, rather than Perl or Java, the reader should always consult the
Database Schema
to understand the true specification of a data item.

Here is a glossary of data type names used in the function descriptions below:
database handle
Typically some sort of reference. Each language binding defines a data type which is appropriate.
pair list
A container which holds a list of field names and their associated field values, or references to names and values, depending on the language.
positive integer
A whole number, at least 32 bits in length.
row
A container that can hold a sequence of field values or references to field values, depending on the language.
row-array
An array of rows.
string
A sequence of bytes, this type may contain binary data and may be many megabytes in length.
true, false
Values which, in a particular language, are appropriate for "if" statements.

sect3.title: connect -- open a connection to the database

glossdef.para: handle = connect dbname hostname dbuser dbpassword

Connect opens a connection to a database, returning a handle that represents this connection when passed as an argument to other functions in the API. A process may have several connections open simultaneously. Because each connection ties up resources in the RDBMS, it is important to use the disconnect function to close a connection as soon as it is no longer needed.
None.
None.

row.entry: Handle to an open database connection.

Failure occurs when the database user does not have permission to connect to the named database on the given host, when the password is incorrect, or when the maximum number of handles has been exceeded. Additional error information is available in the individual language bindings.
Internet host at which from which user is permitted to make a connection.
Username for database access. This is not the username of an Spk user.
Password for database access. This is not the password of an Spk user.

sect3.title: disconnect -- close a connection to a database

glossdef.para: r = disconnect handle
An open database connection is closed, thus releasing resources in the RDBMS.
None.
None.

row.entry: Failure can occur if the handle is invalid. Additional error information is available in the individual language bindings.
The handle returned by a previous call to the connect function.

sect3.title: new_job -- submit a new job

glossdef.para: job_id = new_job handle user_id abstract dataset_id dataset_version model_id model_version xml_source method_code parent is_warm_start is_mail_notice
A new job is created by adding a row to the job table. The value of the job_id field of this row is returned.
The state_code field of the job is set to 'q2c'.
The event_time field is set to the time of insertion.
A state transition record is appended to the history table.
None, assuming that the database supports transactions with autocommit (eg., MySQL database with TYPE=InnoDB) and that the job_id field carries the auto_increment modifier.

row.entry: Unique value of the job_id field of a newly created row in the job table.
Failure occurs if the handle, the user_id, or the model_id are invalid. Additional error information is available in the individual language bindings.
A handle to an open database connection.
Key to the user's row in the user table.
Key to a row in the dataset table, which contains in its archive field an RCS-compatible archive comprising the current version and all previous versions of a dataset.
Key to a row in the model table, which contains in its archive field an RCS-compatible archive comprising the current version and all previous versions of a model.
An XML document containing source code for the model, constraints, parameters and presentation directives.
The method that is to be used for the computation.
The job_id of the job which is the parent of this one. If the job has no parent, this value should be zero.
True for being a warm start job; false for otherwise.
True for requesting end-job mail notice; false for otherwise.

sect3.title: job_status -- return the current state of a job

glossdef.para: row = job_status handle job_id
The state_code, the event_time of the most recent state transition, and the end_code (which may be null) are returned.
None.
None.

row.entry: state_code, event_time, end_code (end_code will be null unless state_code = 'end')
Failure occurs if the handle or job_id is invalid. Additional error information is available in the individual language bindings.
Handle to an open database connection.
Key to a row in the job table.

sect3.title: job_history -- retrieve history for a given job

glossdef.para: row-array = job_history handle job_id
All rows of the history table that correspond to a given job_id are returned. Each row describes a state transition.

row.entry: An array containing all history for the given job
Failure occurs if their is no history for the job_id. Additional error information depends on the individual language bindings.
Handle to an open database connection.
Key to a row in the job table.

sect3.title: get_job -- retrieve a row from the job table

glossdef.para: row = get_job handle job_id
This function retrieves the entire row from the job table that corresponds to the given job_id.

row.entry: An entire row of the job table.
The case where there is no row corresponding to the job id is distinguishable from a failure due to database error.
Handle to an open database connection.
A valid key to the job table.

sect3.title: user_jobs -- get status for user's most recent jobs

glossdef.para: row-array = user_jobs handle user_id maxnum

Returns an array of rows, each of which contains the current status of one of a given user's jobs. Jobs are sorted in reverse order of job_id, hence the most recently submitted job appears first. The maximum number of jobs to return is given as one of the arguments.
None.
None, assuming that the database supports consistent reads (as does MySQL database, with type=InnoDB).

row.entry: In each row: job_id, abstract, state_code, start_time, event_time, end_code
Failure occurs if the handle or user_id is invalid. Additional error information is available in the individual language bindings.
Handle to an open database connection.
Key to the user's row in the user table.
Maximum number of rows to be returned. For example, if only the status of the most recent job is desired, this argument would have the value 1.

sect3.title: de_q2c -- select highest priority job from compiler queue

glossdef.para: row = de_q2c handle
The job table is queried to find the highest priority job with state_code equal to 'q2c'. If the queue is not empty, the fields needed by the Aspk Compiler are returned.
The state code field of the job is set to cmp.
The event_time field is updated to the time of this state transition.
A state transition record is added to the history table.

The work of this function is performed within transaction state, between a begin database command and a commit. The job is found by using a select for update command. In case of error, the functions performs a rollback before exiting.

row.entry: Information that can be used to differentiate between an empty queue and an error condition such as an invalid handle is provided by the individual language bindings.
Handle to an open database connection.

sect3.title: get_cmp_jobs -- get all jobs currently being compiled

glossdef.para: row-array = get_cmp_jobs handle

An array of rows containing all jobs with state_code = 'cmp' is returned. The rows contain the fields job_id, dataset_id and xml_source. This function would typically be called by the compiler deamon upon starting up, in order to discover any jobs which were being compiled when the the compiler sub-system was shut down, so that those jobs could be compiled again.
None.
None.

row.entry: In each row: job_id, dataset_id, dataset_version, and xml_source
Information that can be used to differentiate between a select that returns the empty set and a database error condition is provided by the individual language bindings.
Handle to an open database connection.

sect3.title: en_q2r -- add a compiled job to the run queue

glossdef.para: r = en_q2r handle job_id cpp_source
The Aspk Compiler uses this function to move a job that it has compiled to the queue of jobs that are ready to be run by the Cspk.
The state_code field of the job is changed to 'q2r'.
The cpp_source field of the job contains c++ source code.
The event_time field is updated to the time of this state transition.
A state transition record is added to the history table.
None, assuming that the database supports updates with autocommit (eg. MySQL with type=InnoDB).

row.entry: Failure occurs if the handle or job_id is invalid. Additional error information is available in the individual language bindings.
A handle to an open database connection.
Key to a row in the job table.
An archive of text files in compressed tar format.

sect3.title: de_q2r -- select the highest priority job from the run queue

glossdef.para: row = de_q2r handle
The job table is queried for the highest priority job with state_code equal to 'q2r'. If the queue is not empty, the fields needed by Cspk are returned.
The state code field of the job is set to 'run'.
The event_time field is updated to the time of this state transition.
A state transition record is added to the history table.

The work of this function is performed within transaction state, between a begin database command and a commit. The job is found by using a select for update command. In case of error, the functions performs a rollback before exiting.

row.entry: Information that can be used to distinguish between an empty queue and an error condition such as an invalid handle is provided in each of the language bindings.
Handle to an open database connection.

sect3.title: get_run_jobs -- get all jobs currently being running

glossdef.para: row-array = get_run_jobs handle

An array of rows containing all jobs with state_code = 'run' is returned. Each row contains only the field: job_id. This function would typically be called by the runtime deamon upon starting up, in order to discover any jobs which were being run when the the computational sub-system was shut down, so that those jobs could be restarted.
None.
None.

row.entry: Information that can be used to differentiate between a select that returns the empty set and a database error condition is provided by the individual language bindings.
Handle to an open database connection.

sect3.title: end_job -- end a job, whether successful or not

glossdef.para: r = end_job handle job_id end_code report checkpoint
Cause a job to make the transition to the End state. This can occur at the end of a successful run, at the end of a failed run, or in case of errors occurring during Aspk compilation.
Note: this function cannot be used to terminate a compilation or a run. It is used, instead, to record the fact that the job has terminated or completed.
The state_code field of the job is changed to 'end'.
The end_code of the job is changed to $end_code.
The report field contains a report.
The event_time field is updated to the time of this state transition.
None, assuming that the database supports updates and inserts with autocommit (eg. MySQL with type=InnoDB).

row.entry: Failure occurs when the handle, job_id, or end_code is invalid. Additional error information is available in the individual language bindings.
Handle to an open database connection.
Key to a row in the job table.
Valid key to a row in the end table.
XML containing the final report, whether the results of successful computation, partial results after an incomplete run, or description of an error condition.
XML containing the checkpoint file, in case the job completed without errors. Otherwise, the string should be null.

sect3.title: job_report -- retrieve the final report for a job

glossdef.para: report = job_report handle job_id
The final report, in XML, is returned.
None.
None.

row.entry: A string containing a complete XML document.
Failure occurs if the handle or job_id is invalid. The language bindings return additional information about error conditions.
Handle to an open database connection.
Key to a row in the job table.

sect3.title: new_dataset -- add a dataset to the database

glossdef.para: dataset_id = new_dataset handle user_id name abstract archive

The dataset table contains the source code for scientific datasets along with identification information. The archive field is an RCS-compatible file which contains the current and all previous versions of the XML text of the dataset. This function is used to establish the initial version of a dataset in the database.
The event_time field is set to the time of insertion.

None, assuming that the database supports transactions with autocommit (eg., MySQL database with TYPE=InnoDB), that the dataset_id field carries the auto_increment and that the name field is unique for the given user_id due to a UNIQUE user_id (user_id, name) modifier.

row.entry: Key to a row newly added to the dataset table.
Failure occurs if the or the user_id is invalid. Additional information about the nature of the failure is provided by individual language bindings.
Handle to an open database connection.
Key to a row in the user table.

sect3.title: get_dataset -- retrieve a dataset

glossdef.para: list = get_dataset handle dataset_id
Given the key into the dataset table, the corresponding row is returned.
None.
None.

row.entry: List of all field names for the dataset table, along with associated values.
Failure occurs if the handle or the dataset_id is invalid. Information that can be used to distinguish a missing row from an error is provided by the individual language bindings.
Handle to an open database connection.
Key to a row in the dataset table.

sect3.title: update_dataset -- update a row in the dataset table

glossdef.para: update_dataset handle dataset_id list

A set of fields in a row of the dataset table are updated. It is not necessary to update all rows. The list is a set of (name, value) pairs, which specifies the names of fields and the new values which are to be stored into them.
The event_time field is set to the time of the update.

None, assuming that the database supports transactions with autocommit (eg., MySQL database with TYPE=InnoDB) and that the name field is unique for the given user_id due to a UNIQUE user_id (user_id, name) modifier.

row.entry: Failure occurs if the handle or the dataset_id is invalid. Individual language bindings provide additional information in case of error.
Handle to an open database connection.
Key to a row in the dataset table.
The list consists of names of fields in the dataset table and the corresponding values that should replace current values.

sect3.title: user_datasets -- get a user's datasets

glossdef.para: row-array = user_datasets handle user_id
Returns an array of rows, each of which contains a description of one of a given user's datasets. Rows are sorted in order of dataset_id.
None.
None, assuming that the database supports consistent reads (as does MySQL database, with type=InnoDB).

row.entry: In each row: dataset_id, name, abstract.
Failure occurs if the handle or user_id is invalid. Individual language bindings provide information sufficient to recognize the case where no datasets for this user exist and to identify faults.
Handle to an open database connection.
Key to a row in the user table.

sect3.title: new_model -- add a model to the database

glossdef.para: model_id = new_model handle user_id name abstract archive

The model table contains the source code for scientific models along with identification information. The archive field is an RCS-compatible file which contains the current and all previous versions of the XML text of the model. This function is used to establish the initial version of a model in the database.
The event_time field is set to the time of insertion.

None, assuming that the database supports transactions with autocommit (eg., MySQL database with TYPE=InnoDB), that the model_id field carries the auto_increment and that the name field is unique for the given user_id due to a UNIQUE user_id (user_id, name) modifier.

row.entry: Key to a row newly added to the model table.
Failure occurs if the or the user_id is invalid. Additional information about the nature of the failure is provided by individual language bindings.
Handle to an open database connection.
Key to a row in the user table.

sect3.title: get_model -- retrieve a model

glossdef.para: list = get_model handle model_id
Given the key into the model table, the corresponding row is returned.
None.
None.

row.entry: List of all field names for the model table, along with associated values.
Failure occurs if the handle or the model_id is invalid. Information that can be used to distinguish a missing row from an error is provided by the individual language bindings.
Handle to an open database connection.
Key to a row in the model table.

sect3.title: update_model -- update a row in the model table

glossdef.para: update_model handle model_id list

A set of fields in a row of the model table are updated. It is not necessary to update all rows. The list is a set of (name, value) pairs, which specifies the names of fields and the new values which are to be stored into them.
The event_time field is set to the time of the update.

None, assuming that the database supports transactions with autocommit (eg., MySQL database with TYPE=InnoDB) and that the name field is unique for the given user_id due to a UNIQUE user_id (user_id, name) modifier.

row.entry: Failure occurs if the handle or the model_id is invalid. Individual language bindings provide additional information in case of error.
Handle to an open database connection.
Key to a row in the model table.
The list consists of names of fields in the model table and the corresponding values that should replace current values.

sect3.title: user_models -- get a user's models

glossdef.para: row-array = user_models handle user_id
Returns an array of rows, each of which contains a description of one of a given user's models. Rows are sorted in order of model_id.
None.
None, assuming that the database supports consistent reads (as does MySQL database, with type=InnoDB).

row.entry: In each row: model_id, name, abstract.
Failure occurs if the handle or user_id is invalid. Individual language bindings provide information sufficient to recognize the case where no models for this user exist and to identify faults.
Handle to an open database connection.
Key to a row in the user table.

sect3.title: new_user -- add a new user

glossdef.para: user_id = new_user handle username password ...
Add a new Spk user.
None.
None, assuming that the database supports transactions with autocommit (eg., MySQL database with TYPE=InnoDB) and that the user_id field carries the auto_increment modifier.

row.entry: Key to a row newly added to the user table.

Failure occurs if the handle is invalid, or if the list does not include at least a unique username and a password. Additional information about the nature of the failure is provided by individual language bindings.
Handle to an open database connection.

A list if names of fields in the user table, along with values to be stored in the corresponding fields. This list must include, at a minimum, username and password, along with their associated values.

sect3.title: update_user -- update a row in the user table

glossdef.para: r = update_user handle user_id list
Update fields of the row in the user table that corresponds to user_id.
None.
None, assuming that the database supports transactions with autocommit (eg., MySQL database with TYPE=InnoDB).

row.entry: Failure occurs if the handle or the user_id is invalid. Individual language bindings provide additional information in case of error.
Handle to an open database connection.
Key to a row in the user table.
The list consists of names of fields in the user table and the corresponding values that should replace current values.

sect3.title: get_user -- retrieve a user record by username

glossdef.para: list = get_user handle username
This function retrieves the entire row in the user table corresponding to the username. Since username is a unique alternative key, there will be no more than one row returned.
None.
None, assuming that the database supports consistent reads (as does MySQL database, with type=InnoDB).

row.entry: List of all field names for the user table, along with their associated values.
Failure occurs if the handle or the username is invalid. Information sufficient to distinguish the case of a nonexistent user from various error conditions is provided by the language bindings.
Handle to an open database connection.
User name for logging in to Spk via the MDA.

sect3.title: get_end_table - - return the entire end table

glossdef.para: row-array = get_end_table handle
The end table maps end codes into their English language equivalents. The table is not very large, hence it is most efficient for the function to return the entire table.

row.entry: The database "select" that this function performs should never come up empty, hence the only basis for failure would be a database error, in which case the result would be null or undefined, depending on the language binding.
Handle to an open database connection.

sect3.title: get_method_table - - return the entire method table

glossdef.para: row-array = get_method_table handle
The method table maps method codes into their English language equivalents. The table is not very large, hence it is most efficient for the function to return the entire table.

row.entry: The database "select" that this function performs should never come up empty, hence the only basis for failure would be a database error, in which case the result would be null or undefined, depending on the language binding.
Handle to an open database connection.

sect3.title: get_state_table - - return the entire state table

glossdef.para: row-array = get_state_table handle
The state table maps state codes into their English language equivalents. The table is not very large, hence it is most efficient for the function to return the entire table.

row.entry: The database "select" that this function performs should never come up empty, hence the only basis for failure would be a database error, in which case the result would be null or undefined, depending on the language binding.
Handle to an open database connection.

sect3.title: abort job -- abort a job

glossdef.para: r = abort_job handle job_id

Abort a job when the job is in one of the four possible states. If the job's state_code equals to 'q2c', set the job's state_code to 'end' and the job's end_code to 'abrt'. If the job's state_code equals to 'cmp', set the job's state_code to 'q2ac'- queued to abort compiling. If the job's state_code equals to 'q2r', set the job's state_code to 'end' and the job's end_code to 'abrt'. If the job's state_code equals to 'run', set the job's state_code to 'q2ar' - queued to abort running.
The event_time field is updated to the time of this transition.
A state transition record is appended to the history table.
None, assuming that the database supports transactions with autocommit (eg., MySQL database with TYPE=InnoDB) and that the job_id field carries the auto_increment modifier.

row.entry: The job's state_code has been set to either 'end, 'q2ac' or q2ar'.
The job's state_code has not been set to either 'end, 'q2ac' or q2ar'
Handle to an open database connection.
A valid key to the job table.

sect3.title: get job ids -- get all job ids with a given state_code

glossdef.para: list = get_job_ids handle state_code
Get job_ids of all jobs as an array with a given state_code.
None.
None, assuming that the database supports transactions with autocommit (eg., MySQL database with TYPE=InnoDB) and that the job_id field carries the auto_increment modifier.

row.entry: An array of job_ids of all the jobs with the given state_code, 0 if there is no job with the given state_code
Failure occurs if the handle or job_id is invalid. Additional error information is available in the individual language bindings.
Handle to an open database connection.
state_code of the jobs to get.

sect3.title: de_q2ac -- remove highest priority job from aborting compiler queue

glossdef.para: job_id = de_q2ac handle
Remove the highest priority job from the aborting compiler queue, so that it can be aborted by the compiler daemon.
The state_code field of the job is set to acmp.
The event_time field is updated to the time of this state transition.
A state transition record is added to the history table.

The work of this function is performed within transaction state, between a begin database command and a commit. The job is found by using a select for update command. In case of error, the functions performs a rollback before exiting.

row.entry: job_id of highest priority aborting compilation job, false if aborting compiler queue is empty
Failure occurs if the handle is invalid. Additional error information is available in the individual language bindings.
Handle to an open database connection.

sect3.title: de_q2ar -- remove highest priority job from aborting run queue

glossdef.para: job_id = de_q2ar handle
Remove the highest priority job from the aborting run queue, so that it can be aborted by the run-time daemon.
The state_code field of the job is set to arun.
The event_time field is updated to the time of this state transition.
A state transition record is added to the history table.

The work of this function is performed within transaction state, between a begin database command and a commit. The job is found by using a select for update command. In case of error, the functions performs a rollback before exiting.

row.entry: job_id of highest priority aborting run job, false if aborting run queue is empty
Failure occurs if the handle is invalid. Additional error information is available in the individual language bindings.
Handle to an open database connection.

sect3.title: get_mail_notice -- get end-job email notice request option

glossdef.para: r = get_mail_notice handle job_id
Given a job_id, get end-job email notice request option for the job.
None.
None, as long as the job_id is valid.

row.entry: true if the end-job email notice request option is set, false if otherwise
Failure occurs if the handle is invalid. Additional error information is available in the individual language bindings.
Handle to an open database connection.
The key to a row in the job table.

sect3.title: get_user_by_id -- retrieve a user record by user_id

glossdef.para: list = get_user_by_id handle user_id
This function retrieves the entire row in the user table corresponding to the user_id. Since user_id is a unique key, there will be no more than one row returned.
None.
None, assuming that the database supports consistent reads (as does MySQL database, with type=InnoDB).

row.entry: List of all field names for the user table, along with their associated values.
Failure occurs if the handle or the user_id is invalid. Information sufficient to distinguish the case of a nonexistent user from various error conditions is provided by the language bindings.
Handle to an open database connection.

sect3.title: set_job_abstract -- set job abstract.

glossdef.para: r = set_job_abstract handle job_id
This function sets the job abstact job table corresponding to the job_id.
None.
None, assuming that the database supports consistent reads (as does MySQL database, with type=InnoDB).

row.entry: Failure occurs if the handle, the user_id or the job_id is invalid.
Handle to an open database connection.

sect3.title: new_group -- add a new group

glossdef.para: group_id = new_group handle group_name
Add a new Spk user group.
None.
None, assuming that the database supports transactions with autocommit (eg., MySQL database with TYPE=InnoDB) and that the group_id field carries the auto_increment modifier.

row.entry: Key to a row newly added to the team table.

Failure occurs if the handle is invalid, or if the group_name has already been used by an existing group. Additional information about the nature of the failure is provided by individual language bindings.
Handle to an open database connection.

sect3.title: new_group_member -- add a new group member

glossdef.para: r = new_group_member handle username group_id
Add a user to a group.
None.
None, assuming that the database supports transactions with autocommit (eg., MySQL database with TYPE=InnoDB).

row.entry: Group ID is set to the user in the user table.
Failure occurs if the handle is invalid, or if the username or the group_id is invalid. Additional information about the nature of the failure is provided by individual language bindings.
Handle to an open database connection.

sect3.title: get_group_users -- retrieve all users of a group

glossdef.para: list = get_group_users handle group_id
This function retrieves the a list of entire rows in the user table corresponding to the group_id.
None.
None, assuming that the database supports consistent reads (as does MySQL database, with type=InnoDB).

row.entry: List of all field names for the user table, along with their associated values.
Failure occurs if the handle or the group_id is invalid. Information sufficient to distinguish the case of a nonexistent user from various error conditions is provided by the language bindings.
Handle to an open database connection.
